title: Moules Marinières with Fries
description: Classic French mussels steamed in a fragrant white-wine, garlic, shallot and herb broth served with crisp, hand-cut fries. Bright, briny mussels and buttery-scented broth pair perfectly with hot, crunchy fries for a comforting bistro-style meal.

ingredients.notes: discard any open mussels that do not close when tapped; rinse and remove beards

ingredients.display_name: dry white wine (like sauvignon blanc or muscadet)

ingredients.notes: divided: some for broth, some for finishing
for frying fries and sautéing aromatics
packed chopped; reserve some for garnish
plus more for fries boiling and seasoning

ingredients.display_name: lemon, halved and cut into wedges
russet potatoes, peeled (or scrubbed) and cut into 1/3-inch fries
ingredients.notes: soaked in cold water to remove excess starch
enough for shallow or deep frying

ingredients.display_name: all-purpose flour (optional for a light dredge of fries)
ingredients.notes: toss fries lightly for extra crispness

steps.text: Prepare mussels: remove beards, scrub shells, discard any broken or open mussels that don't close when tapped; place cleaned mussels in the refrigerator until ready.
Soak and par-cook fries: cut potatoes into 1/3-inch sticks, place in cold water and soak 20 minutes to 1 hour (shorter soaking counted here); drain and pat dry thoroughly.

Start fries first fry (blanch): heat vegetable oil to 300°F (if using thermometer) or medium-low; fry potato sticks in batches until tender but not colored (about 4–5 minutes per batch); remove to a wire rack and drain.

Make mussel broth: in a large wide pot or Dutch oven over medium heat, add olive oil and 2 tbsp butter; sauté sliced shallots until translucent, then add minced garlic and cook briefly until fragrant (about 1 minute).
Deglaze and steam: add white wine, bay leaves, half the chopped parsley, salt and pepper; bring to a brisk simmer to burn off some alcohol (about 2 minutes).

Add mussels to the pot, cover tightly and increase heat to maintain a vigorous steam; cook until mussels open, shaking the pot occasionally, about 5–6 minutes. Discard any mussels remaining closed after cooking.

Finish broth: remove lid, transfer mussels with tongs to serving bowls leaving cooking liquid in pot; reduce liquid briefly if needed, then swirl in remaining butter and adjust seasoning; stir in remaining parsley and a squeeze of lemon.

Second fry and season fries: heat oil to higher temperature (about 375°F) or medium-high; fry blanched fries in batches until golden and crisp, about 3–4 minutes per batch; drain on paper or rack and immediately season with coarse salt.
Serve: spoon hot broth over mussels in bowls, garnish with lemon wedges and extra parsley; serve fries immediately on side or in cones for dipping into broth.
